question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump Sr. is the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican nomination, with other candidates like Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley also in the race. Donald Trump Jr. has not announced any intention to run. 2. Name recognition: While Donald Trump Jr. has a high profile due to his father's presidency, he has never held elected office himself, which could be a significant disadvantage. 3. Political experience: Compared to other potential candidates, Donald Trump Jr. lacks direct political experience, which voters and party officials often consider important for a presidential nominee. 4. Family dynamics: It's unlikely that both Donald Trump Sr. and Jr. would run in the same election cycle, as this could split their base of support. If Trump Sr. remains in the race, it's highly improbable that Jr. would enter. 5. Party preferences: The Republican Party typically favors candidates with governmental experience or a strong political track record, which Donald Trump Jr. lacks. 6. Time until convention: While there's still time until the 2024 Republican National Convention, Donald Trump Jr. has not shown any signs of preparing for a presidential run. 7. Current focus: Donald Trump Jr. seems more focused on supporting his father's political endeavors and engaging in political commentary rather than pursuing his own candidacy. 8. Polling data: Current polls do not show significant support for Donald Trump Jr. as a potential nominee compared to other candidates. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that Donald Trump Jr. will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While unexpected events could change the political landscape, based on the current situation, the probability is very low.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless facing significant health issues or extremely low approval ratings. Biden is the incumbent, which gives him a strong position within the party. 2. Current intentions: As of now (July 2023), Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election in 2024. He officially launched his campaign in April 2023. 3. Age and health concerns: Biden is currently 80 years old and would be 82 at the start of a second term. While his health appears stable, concerns about his age and stamina persist. 4. Approval ratings: Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, hovering around 40-45% in recent months. However, they're not catastrophically low to the point where the party would force him out. 5. Democratic Party support: Despite some concerns, the Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden's re-election bid. There's no significant push within the party for an alternative candidate. 6. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's highly unlikely for a sitting president to drop out so late in the process. 7. Potential successors: There's no clear alternative candidate who has been positioning themselves to take over if Biden steps aside. Given these factors, it seems highly improbable that Biden would announce he's not accepting the nomination, especially so late in the process. The only scenario where this might happen would be a sudden, severe health issue, which is unpredictable but relatively unlikely.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Legal precedent: There have been attempts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify candidates, but it's rarely been successful. The most notable recent case was the attempt to remove Marjorie Taylor Greene from the ballot in Georgia, which failed. 2. Current legal challenges: As of now, there are ongoing efforts in multiple states to remove Trump from the ballot using the 14th Amendment. Colorado and Minnesota have seen significant legal battles on this issue. 3. State-level decisions: Different states may interpret and apply the 14th Amendment differently. Some states might be more inclined to remove Trump from the ballot than others. 4. Time frame: The resolution date is July 15, 2024, which gives ample time for legal challenges to be filed, heard, and potentially appealed. 5. Political climate: The issue is highly politicized, which could influence decision-making processes in different states. 6. Supreme Court involvement: Given the high-profile nature of this issue, it's likely that any state-level decision to remove Trump from the ballot would be appealed to the Supreme Court. The Court's decision would likely set a precedent for all states. 7. Trump's actions and statements: His involvement in the January 6th events and subsequent statements could be used as evidence in these cases. 8. Constitutional interpretation: There's debate among legal scholars about whether Section 3 of the 14th Amendment can be applied without additional legislation. Given these factors, I believe there is a significant chance that at least one state might remove or block Trump from the primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. However, it's far from certain. The legal and political hurdles are substantial, and there's a good chance that even if a state does make such a decision, it could be overturned by higher courts before the resolution date.

Otherwise, resolves NO.

Short timeframe: The question asks about a very specific and short timeframe - approximately 3 weeks from the creation date to the resolution date. Given these factors, the probability of Joe Biden dying before Saturday, July 27, 2024, is very low. While it's impossible to predict with absolute certainty, and unexpected events can always occur, the combination of his current health status, the short timeframe, and the security measures in place make it highly unlikely.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current health and age: Biden is currently 80 years old (born November 20, 1942). While he has maintained relatively good health, his advanced age does increase the risk of health issues. 2. Historical precedent: No U.S. President has died in office since John F. Kennedy in 1963, and no President has resigned since Richard Nixon in 1974. This suggests a low probability of either event occurring. 3. Political stability: As of now, there are no major political crises or scandals that would likely lead to Biden's resignation. 4. Time frame: The question only asks about a period of approximately one month (from the creation date to the end of July 2024). This short timeframe reduces the likelihood of unexpected events occurring. 5. 2024 Election: While the 2024 presidential election will be approaching, it won't take place until November, well after the period in question. 6. 25th Amendment clause: The question specifically states that temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment does not count as ceasing to be President, which eliminates one potential way Biden might briefly not be serving as President. 7. Biden's commitment: Biden has shown no indications of wanting to step down from the presidency and has expressed interest in running for re-election in 2024. Given these factors, the probability of Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 is quite high. The main risk factors are his age and the possibility of unexpected health issues, but these are mitigated by the short time frame in question and his current good health.

Resolves NO otherwise. Note: Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not impact the resolution as long as he remains President.

While he has had some health issues in the past, there have been no recent reports of severe health concerns that would suggest an imminent risk of death. 2. Likelihood of sudden death: For any individual, especially at an advanced age, there's always a possibility of sudden death due to various factors like heart attack, stroke, or accident. However, as the President, Biden receives excellent medical care and constant monitoring, which reduces this risk. 3. Time frame: The question specifies a very short time frame - from July 5, 2024 (creation date) to July 26, 2024 (market close on Friday). This is only about three weeks, which is an extremely short period for such a significant event to occur. 4. Continuation as President after death: The second part of the condition, that Biden remains President through the end of July 2024 even after death, is highly improbable. In the event of a President's death, the Vice President immediately assumes the role of President as per the U.S. Constitution. 5. Historical precedent: No U.S. President has died in office since John F. Kennedy in 1963, and none have remained 'President' after death. Given these factors, the probability of this scenario occurring is extremely low. The combination of Biden dying within this short timeframe AND somehow remaining President after death makes this scenario highly implausible.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Existing opposition: The context already mentions that "dozens" of House Democrats are organizing to speak out against the early nomination plan. This suggests there is significant opposition within the party. 2. Time frame: The market closes on July 21st, which gives about a week for the letter to be finalized and signed. This is a relatively short time, but not impossibly so for organizing such an effort. 3. Number of signatures required: The threshold of 20 signatures is relatively low, considering there are currently 213 Democratic Representatives in the House and 48 Democratic Senators (plus 3 Independents who caucus with Democrats). 4. Motivation: The opposition seems to stem from concerns about stifling debate and achieving forced unity, which could be important issues for many Democratic lawmakers. 5. Political climate: With the 2024 election approaching and the mentioned assassination attempt on Trump, there's likely to be heightened political tension and scrutiny on party decisions. 6. Precedent: Democrats have shown willingness to publicly disagree with party leadership in the past, especially on procedural matters. 7. Rep. Huffman's involvement: While he declined to confirm the letter's existence, his willingness to speak about the opposition suggests the effort is serious. 8. Potential backlash: Some lawmakers might be hesitant to sign due to fear of party repercussions or appearing disloyal to Biden. Given these factors, it seems quite likely that a letter will be produced and signed by at least 20 Democratic lawmakers. The existing organization, the relatively low threshold of signatures needed, and the short but manageable timeframe all point towards a high probability of success. However, there's still some uncertainty due to potential hesitation from lawmakers and the possibility of the effort falling short in the given time.

question.body:
This question resolves to YES if both of the following conditions are met:

1. A public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before the end of Sunday, July 21st. This includes multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the USA winning more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics, we need to consider several factors: 1. In recent Summer Olympics, they have typically won more Gold medals than Silver: - Tokyo 2020 (2021): 39 Gold, 41 Silver - Rio 2016: 46 Gold, 37 Silver - London 2012: 46 Gold, 29 Silver - Beijing 2008: 36 Gold, 38 Silver 2. Strength of the US team: The USA has strong programs in swimming, athletics, gymnastics, and many other sports, which contribute significantly to their Gold medal count. 3. Competition from other countries: While the USA is strong, other nations like China, ROC (Russian Olympic Committee), and Japan have been improving their performances, which could impact the USA's medal distribution. 4. Home advantage: The USA won't have a home advantage in Paris, which could slightly decrease their overall performance compared to a home Olympics. 5. Variability in performance: Olympic results can be unpredictable, with small margins often separating Gold from Silver. 6. COVID-19 impact: The pandemic's long-term effects on athlete training and development could influence performance, though this impact should be less significant by 2024. Looking at the recent history, the USA has won more Gold than Silver medals in three out of the last four Summer Olympics. The exception was Tokyo 2020, where they won slightly more Silver than Gold, possibly due to pandemic-related disruptions and the rise of other nations' competitiveness. Given the USA's consistent strong performance and their tendency to win more Gold than Silver, I believe it's more likely than not that they will achieve this in Paris 2024. However, the increasing competitiveness of other nations and the unpredictability of Olympic performances introduce some uncertainty.

Precedent: There has never been a father-son ticket for a major party nomination in U.S. presidential history. This lack of precedent makes such a scenario highly unlikely. 3. Republican Party dynamics: While Donald Trump maintains significant influence within the Republican Party, there is also a growing faction seeking to move beyond the Trump era. Nominating both Trumps would likely be seen as excessive and potentially alienating to moderate voters. 4. This lack of direct political experience makes him an unlikely choice for a vice-presidential nominee. 5. Other potential candidates: There are numerous other experienced Republican politicians who would likely be considered for the vice-presidential nomination before Donald Trump Jr., including current governors, senators, and former administration officials. 6. Public perception: A father-son ticket might be perceived negatively by many voters as an attempt to establish a political dynasty, which could be unpopular even among some Trump supporters. 7. Legal challenges: Donald Trump is currently facing various legal issues, which could potentially impact his ability to run or his appeal as a candidate. This uncertainty makes the scenario of both Trumps being nominated even less likely. Given these factors, it is extremely improbable that both Donald Trump and Donald Trump Jr. would be nominated as the Republican candidates for the 2024 US Presidential Election. question.title: Will at least 5 countries win their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Games?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of at least 5 countries winning their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Paris Games, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical precedent: In recent Olympics, it's been relatively common for a few countries to win their first medals. For example: - Tokyo 2020: 3 countries (Burkina Faso, San Marino, Turkmenistan) - Rio 2016: 3 countries (Fiji, Jordan, Kosovo) - London 2012: 5 countries (Cyprus, Grenada, Guatemala, Montenegro, South Sudan) 2. Number of participating countries: The Olympics typically feature around 200 nations. As of 2021, there were still about 72 countries that had never won an Olympic medal. 3. Emerging sports: The 2024 Paris Olympics will include new sports like breaking (breakdancing), which could provide opportunities for countries with strengths in these areas to win their first medals. 4. Development of sports programs: Many countries have been investing in their Olympic programs, increasing the chances of breakthrough performances. 5. Geopolitical changes: New countries or recently recognized nations may participate for the first time or with renewed focus. 6. Expanded opportunities: The IOC has been working to increase participation and representation from a wider range of countries, which could lead to more first-time medalists. 7. Random chance: With so many events and athletes competing, there's always a possibility of unexpected results. Given these factors, it seems quite possible that at least 5 countries could win their first Olympic medal in Paris 2024. The historical precedent shows that it's not uncommon for 3-5 countries to achieve this in a single Olympics. With new sports, continued development of Olympic programs in various countries, and the large number of nations still seeking their first medal, the chances appear favorable. However, it's not a certainty. The more established sporting nations still dominate many events, and breakthrough performances are still relatively rare. The target of 5 countries is also at the higher end of what we've seen in recent Games. Considering all these factors, I would estimate the probability to be moderately high, but not overwhelmingly so.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political climate: There's growing concern among Democrats about Biden's age and electability, as evidenced by the Politico report mentioned. 2. Existing dissent: Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden to drop out, and two endangered Democrats have expressed pessimism about his chances. 3. Behind-the-scenes activity: Multiple drafts of letters are reportedly circulating among House Democrats, with at least one calling for Biden to end his campaign. 4. Time frame: The question asks about this happening before July 20th, which is about 2.5 weeks from now. This is a relatively short period for such a significant political move. 5. Political risk: Publicly calling for the incumbent president of your own party to drop out is a major political risk. Many Democrats might be hesitant to do this, fearing backlash or division within the party. 6. Biden's stance: Biden has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election and hasn't shown signs of considering dropping out. 7. Party unity concerns: The Democratic leadership might work to prevent such a public call to avoid damaging party unity ahead of the election. 8. Precedent: It's unusual for sitting members of Congress to publicly call for their party's incumbent president not to run for re-election. Given these factors, while there is clearly some dissatisfaction and behind-the-scenes activity, it seems unlikely that a group of at least 5 named Democratic House Members or Senators will publicly pressure Biden to drop out in such a short timeframe. The political risks and potential for party disunity are significant deterrents. However, the existence of draft letters and the reported behind-the-scenes activity suggest it's not impossible. If the drafts gain traction quickly or if there's a sudden, significant event that changes the political calculus, it could happen.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

question.title: Will the European Union announce new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

Considering these factors, it seems more likely than not that the EU will announce new tariffs or duties on Chinese EV imports before July 5, 2024. question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

(b) At least 5 named Democratic House Members or Senators pressuring Biden to drop out before July 20, 2024:
- Biden is the incumbent president and presumptive Democratic nominee.
- There have been some concerns about Biden's age and approval ratings.
- However, openly pressuring a sitting president to drop out is a rare and politically risky move.
- The Democratic Party generally tries to present a united front.
- The specific requirement of 5 named individuals acting together makes this even less likely.
- Probability estimate for (b): 0.1

For both events to occur, we need to multiply these probabilities:
0.3 * 0.1 = 0.03

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current health and age: Biden is currently 80 years old (born November 20, 1942). While he has maintained relatively good health, his advanced age does increase the risk of potential health issues. 2. Historical precedent: No U.S. President has died in office since John F. Kennedy in 1963, and no President has resigned since Richard Nixon in 1974. This suggests a generally low probability of a President not completing their term. 3. Biden's commitment to the role: Biden has consistently expressed his intention to serve his full term and has even hinted at running for re-election in 2024. 4. Political stability: There are currently no major political scandals or crises that would suggest Biden might resign. 5. Time frame: The question asks about a period ending in July 2024, which is less than a year away from the current date. This relatively short time frame reduces the likelihood of unforeseen events occurring. 6. Medical advancements: Modern medical care for the President is extensive, which helps mitigate health risks. 7. Succession planning: The 25th Amendment provides a clear process for temporary transfer of power, which reduces the likelihood of resignation due to short-term health issues. Given these factors, the probability of Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 is quite high. While his age does present some increased risk, the historical rarity of presidents not completing their terms, combined with Biden's apparent health and commitment to the role, suggests a strong likelihood of him continuing in office.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This is a complex question that involves legal, political, and constitutional considerations. Let's break down the key factors: 1. Legal precedent: There have been attempts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify candidates, but it has rarely been successfully applied in modern times. The most notable recent case was the removal of Couy Griffin from a county commissioner position in New Mexico in 2022. 2. Current legal challenges: As of now, there are ongoing efforts in multiple states to remove Trump from the ballot using this argument. Colorado and Maine have already made decisions to remove Trump from their primary ballots, citing the 14th Amendment. 3. Supreme Court involvement: The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to hear the Colorado case, with arguments scheduled for February 8, 2024. Their decision will likely set a precedent for other states. 4. Time frame: The resolution date is July 15, 2024, which gives ample time for legal processes to unfold, including potential Supreme Court rulings. 5. Political climate: The issue is highly contentious and politically charged, which could influence decision-making processes in various states. 6. State-by-state variation: Different states may interpret and apply the 14th Amendment differently, potentially leading to varied outcomes across the country. Given these factors, I believe there is a significant chance that at least one state will have removed or blocked Trump from their primary ballot by July 15, 2024. The Colorado and Maine decisions, although currently under appeal, demonstrate that there is a willingness among some state officials to take this action. Even if the Supreme Court rules against Colorado's decision, other states might find alternative legal grounds or interpretations to justify ballot removal. However, the involvement of the Supreme Court adds uncertainty. If they rule decisively against using the 14th Amendment in this way, it could effectively prevent other states from taking similar actions. But given the complexity of the issue, they might leave some room for state-level discretion. Considering all these factors, I believe there is a moderate to high probability that at least one state will have Trump removed or blocked from their primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by the specified date.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Biden remains President through end of July 2024 (b) Donald Trump is removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

(b) Resolves YES if, on July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. Resolves NO if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately and then combine their probabilities. (a) Biden remaining President through end of July 2024: Joe Biden is currently the President of the United States and has not shown any signs of intending to resign. While his age (80 years old) is a factor to consider, he appears to be in relatively good health for his age. The probability of a sitting president not completing their term due to death or resignation is historically low. Since 1900, only 4 out of 20 presidents have not completed their terms (McKinley, Harding, Roosevelt, and Kennedy). This gives us a rough historical probability of about 20% for a president not completing their term. However, given Biden's age, we might adjust this probability slightly higher. Let's estimate the probability of Biden remaining President through July 2024 at around 85%. (b) Donald Trump being removed or blocked from a primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment: This is a more complex and unprecedented situation. The 14th Amendment, Section 3 has rarely been invoked, and never for a presidential candidate of Trump's stature. However, there are ongoing efforts and discussions about using this amendment to prevent Trump from running. Several factors to consider: 1. Legal challenges have already been initiated in some states. 2. The issue is highly contentious and likely to face significant legal battles. 3. Different states may interpret and apply the amendment differently. 4. The Supreme Court may ultimately need to weigh in on this issue. Given the unprecedented nature of this situation and the legal complexities involved, it's difficult to assign a high probability to this occurring. However, given the multiple states where this could potentially happen and the ongoing efforts, there's a non-trivial chance it could occur in at least one state. Let's estimate the probability of this happening at around 30%. For both (a) and (b) to occur, we need to multiply these probabilities: 0.85 * 0.30 = 0.255 or 25.5%. This means there's approximately a 25.5% chance that both Biden remains President through July 2024 AND Trump is removed or blocked from at least one state's primary ballot under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling trends: As of July 5, 2024, Trump is leading Biden by 2.4 points according to the 538 national polling average. This is within the range we're looking for (between 2 and 3 points). 2. Time frame: We're forecasting for July 15, 2024, which is only 10 days from the last known data point. In such a short time, dramatic shifts in polling are less likely unless there's a major event. 3. Historical volatility: Presidential polls tend to fluctuate, but usually within a relatively narrow range in the short term. 4. Potential events: We should consider any known upcoming events that could impact the polls, such as debates, policy announcements, or potential scandals. However, no such events are mentioned in the prompt. 5. Margin of error: Polls typically have a margin of error of around 2-3 percentage points, which means small changes could easily push the lead in or out of our target range. 6. Regression to the mean: If the current 2.4 point lead is seen as unusually high, there might be a slight tendency for it to decrease towards a more typical value. 7. Uncertainty: With any prediction, especially in politics, there's always a degree of uncertainty. Given that the current lead is already within our target range, and considering the short time frame, it seems reasonably likely that Trump's lead will remain between 2 and 3 points. However, there's also a significant chance it could fall below 2 or rise above 3, given normal polling fluctuations and margin of error.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbency advantage: Historically, incumbent presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless faced with significant challenges or health issues. Biden is the incumbent, which typically favors running for re-election. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 years old at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. There have been ongoing discussions about his age and fitness for office, which could potentially influence his decision. 3. Current political climate: As of July 2024, Biden's approval ratings and the overall political landscape will play a crucial role in his decision. If his popularity is low or if there are significant challenges facing the country, it might influence his choice. 4. Party support: The Democratic Party's stance and potential alternative candidates will be important factors. If there's strong support for Biden within the party, it's less likely he would step aside. 5. Personal factors: Biden's own desires, family considerations, and legacy concerns will influence his decision. 6. Timing: The question specifies a deadline of July 15, 2024, which is relatively close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's more likely that a decision not to run would be announced earlier to allow the party time to prepare alternative candidates. 7. Previous statements: Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election, including filing for re-election with the Federal Election Commission in April 2023. Considering these factors, it seems unlikely that Biden would announce he won't accept the nomination this close to the convention, especially given his previous statements and actions indicating his intention to run. While age and health concerns are real factors, they have been known for some time and haven't deterred him so far. The short time frame between the current date (July 1, 2024) and the resolution date (July 15, 2024) also makes it less likely for such a significant change to occur, unless there's an unforeseen major event or health issue. Given these considerations, I believe it's highly unlikely that Biden will announce he won't accept the nomination before July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will Greece qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Greece participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Greece does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Greece qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Greece has a strong track record in Eurovision. Since the introduction of semi-finals in 2004, Greece has qualified for the Grand Final in 16 out of 19 attempts. This gives them an 84% success rate in qualifying. 2. Recent performance: In the last five years (2019-2023), Greece has qualified for the Grand Final four times, missing out only in 2019. This shows a consistent recent performance. 3. Quality of entries: Greece often sends entries that appeal to both jury and televote, which is crucial for qualification. While we don't know the 2024 entry yet, their track record suggests they're likely to send a competitive song. 4. Diaspora voting: Greece benefits from diaspora voting in many European countries, which can help in the televoting portion of the semi-finals. 5. Competitive landscape: The level of competition can vary year to year, but Greece has shown the ability to qualify even in strong years. 6. Potential changes: While unlikely, there's always a small chance of format changes or unforeseen circumstances that could affect qualification chances. 7. Time until the event: As the question was created in April 2024, we're relatively close to the event, reducing uncertainty about participation or major changes. Given Greece's strong historical performance, recent success, and consistent ability to send competitive entries, the chances of qualification appear high. However, Eurovision results can be unpredictable, and there's always a chance of an upset or an unexpectedly weak entry. Considering all these factors, I would estimate a high probability of Greece qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling and forecasts: As of now (July 2023), Biden and Trump are the presumptive nominees for their respective parties, but the election is still over a year away. Current polls show a close race, with some giving Biden a slight edge and others favoring Trump. 2. FiveThirtyEight's methodology: FiveThirtyEight is known for its data-driven approach and tends to be more conservative in its predictions, especially this far out from the election. They consider various factors including polls, economic indicators, and historical trends. 3. Incumbency advantage: Biden is the incumbent president, which historically has provided an advantage, though this effect can vary. 4. Economic factors: The state of the economy in July 2024 will be a significant factor. If the economy is strong, it could favor Biden; if it's weak, it could favor Trump. 5. Political developments: Any major political events or scandals between now and July 2024 could significantly impact the forecast. 6. Historical precedent: FiveThirtyEight has tended to show close races in recent presidential elections, often with slight leads changing hands. Given these factors, I believe it's more likely than not that FiveThirtyEight will show Biden as a slight favorite on July 19, 2024. The incumbency advantage and the tendency for incumbent presidents to have an edge in forecasts this far out from the election are significant factors. However, the race is likely to be close, and there's a substantial chance that Trump could be favored instead. Considering all these factors, I would estimate a 60% chance that FiveThirtyEight will project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024.

question.title: Will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

Current polling: Cheney is not currently a frontrunner in any national polls for the 2024 Republican nomination. Candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and others are consistently polling much higher. 5. Fundraising and support: While Cheney has some support from anti-Trump Republicans and even some Democrats, she lacks the broad party support and fundraising network typically needed to secure a presidential nomination. 6. Time until the convention: The Republican National Convention is still over a year away, which theoretically allows time for significant changes in the political landscape. However, given the current trajectory, a dramatic shift would be needed for Cheney to become a frontrunner. 7. Party unity concerns: The Republican Party is likely to prioritize a candidate who can unite the party's various factions, and Cheney's opposition to Trump has alienated a significant portion of the base. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that Liz Cheney will be selected as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While not impossible, it would require a series of unexpected and dramatic events to shift the party's direction significantly.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Biden is the incumbent, which typically favors running for re-election. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 years old at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. There have been ongoing discussions about his age and fitness for office, which could potentially influence his decision. 3. Current statements and actions: As of now (2023), Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election and has taken steps consistent with a re-election campaign, including fundraising and building campaign infrastructure. 4. Political landscape: The Democratic Party currently lacks a clear alternative candidate with broad support who could step in if Biden were to withdraw. This situation makes it less likely for Biden to step aside. 5. Timing: The question's deadline (July 15, 2024) is very close to the Democratic National Convention, which is typically held in August. It's unlikely that a sitting president would wait until so late in the process to announce they're not seeking re-election, as it would leave the party scrambling to nominate an alternative. 6. Historical precedent: In modern U.S. politics, it's extremely rare for a first-term president to voluntarily decide not to seek re-election. The last time this happened was with Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968, under very different circumstances. 7. Public opinion and approval ratings: While Biden's approval ratings have fluctuated, they haven't reached a level that would typically compel a president to step aside. Considering all these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he's not accepting the nomination before July 15, 2024. While his age and potential health concerns introduce some uncertainty, his current actions and statements, the lack of a clear alternative, and the historical rarity of such a decision all point towards him continuing his re-election bid.

This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbency advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless facing significant health issues or extremely low approval ratings. Biden is the incumbent, which typically favors running for re-election. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 years old at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. There have been ongoing discussions about his age and fitness for office, which could potentially influence his decision. 3. Current political climate: As of July 2024, Biden's approval ratings and the overall political landscape will play a crucial role in his decision. If his approval ratings are very low or if there's a strong push within the Democratic Party for a new candidate, it could increase the chances of him stepping aside. 4. Biden's previous statements: So far, Biden has consistently indicated his intention to run for re-election. In April 2022, he stated that he would be "very fortunate" to run against Donald Trump again in 2024. 5. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is relatively close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's unlikely for an incumbent president to wait this long to announce they're not seeking re-election, as it would leave little time for other candidates to campaign effectively. 6. Party unity: The Democratic Party is likely to prefer avoiding a last-minute change in candidacy, as it could lead to disarray and weaken their position in the general election. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he's not accepting the nomination so close to the convention date. While age and health concerns are real factors, the incumbency advantage and Biden's previous statements strongly suggest he intends to run. The late date specified in the question further reduces the likelihood of such an announcement.

question.title: Will Kamala Harris be the Democratic VP?
question.body: If Kamala Harris is nominated as the Democratic VP, this market will resolve to yes. If someone else is selected as VP, this market will resolve to no. If the VP is changed for any reason after the initial nomination, that will not change the resolution of this market. The market can resolve immediately after the nomination.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Kamala Harris being the Democratic VP nominee for the 2024 election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Kamala Harris is the current Vice President, and historically, incumbent VPs are typically renominated unless there are significant issues or changes in the administration. 2. Biden-Harris relationship: There have been no public indications of a rift between President Biden and VP Harris that would suggest a change in the ticket. 3. Democratic Party unity: Changing the VP nominee could be seen as a sign of instability or lack of confidence in the administration, which the party would likely want to avoid. 4. Demographic representation: Harris brings diversity to the ticket as a woman of color, which is important for the Democratic base. 5. Experience gained: Harris has now had nearly four years of experience as VP, making her more qualified for the role than she was in 2020. 6. Lack of strong alternatives: There are no prominent Democratic figures who have been widely discussed as potential replacements for Harris. 7. Time frame: The market closes on August 10, 2024, which is likely to be after the Democratic National Convention where the VP nominee would be officially confirmed. 8. Potential negatives: Harris has faced some criticism for her performance and approval ratings, but these issues don't seem severe enough to warrant a change. 9. Precedent: It's extremely rare for a party to change VP nominees when a president is running for re-election. The last time this happened was in 1944 when Roosevelt changed from Henry Wallace to Harry Truman. Given these factors, it seems highly likely that Kamala Harris will be renominated as the Democratic VP. While there's always a possibility of unexpected events or changes, the probability of Harris remaining on the ticket is very high.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President, and will Kamala Harris be nominated as the Democratic VP?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following occur:

(a) Prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

(b) Kamala Harris is nominated as the Democratic Vice President (VP). If Kamala Harris is nominated as the Democratic VP, this condition will resolve to yes. If someone else is selected as VP, this condition will resolve to no. If the VP is changed for any reason after the initial nomination, that will not change the resolution of this condition.

If either condition (a) or (b) is not met, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Joe Biden's current stance: As of now, Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election in 2024. He has already launched his campaign and is actively fundraising. 2. Timing: The question specifies an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's extremely rare for a sitting president to drop out so late in the process. 3. Biden's age and health: Biden will be 81 at the time of the 2024 election, which has raised concerns about his ability to serve another term. However, he has maintained that he is fit for office. 4. Democratic Party dynamics: There's no clear successor to Biden within the party, and a last-minute change could be chaotic and potentially damaging to the party's chances. 5. Kamala Harris as VP nominee: While Harris is the current VP and would be a logical choice if Biden were to step down, her approval ratings have been low, and there's no guarantee she would be the automatic choice for VP if a new presidential candidate emerged. 6. Historical precedent: No incumbent president has voluntarily declined to seek re-election this late in the process in modern history. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he's not seeking re-election so close to the convention. The combination of both Biden stepping down AND Harris being nominated as VP is even less likely. While not impossible, this scenario would require a significant and unexpected change in circumstances, such as a sudden health issue for Biden or a major political scandal.
